Fig. 1 Influence of K/Mo. Fig. 1 Reaction conditions: 300 °C. C3H8/O2 with a molar ratio of 8/1. The contact time of each reaction was kept consistent by changing the weight of catalyst. The atomic ratio of Al to Mo remains constant at 0.02/1. Fig. 2 Influence of steam amounts. Fig. 2 Reaction conditions: 300 °C, C3H8/O2 with a molar ratio of 8/1. The contact time of each reaction was kept consistent by changing the weight of catalyst. Fig. 3 Influence of the ratio of alkane to oxygen. Fig. 3 Reaction conditions: 300 °C, catalyst weight, 4.0 g, no steam. Fig. 4 NH3-TPD of the catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine were collected from several catalyst samples after desorption at three different temperatures: (a) 50 °C, (b) 100 °C, (c) 150 °C. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM images of (a) Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Fresh) and (b) Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Used), along with the distribution of several species on Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Fresh): (c) Mo, (d) V, (e) K, (f) Al. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRD patterns of catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XPS spectra of (a) Mo 3d, (b) V 2p for several catalyst samples. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XPS patterns of O 1s with catalysts: (a) Mo1V0.5Ox, (b) Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox, (c) Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Fresh), and (d) Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Used). Compared with propane dehydrogenation (PDH) technology, oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane is an effective way to break through the thermodynamic constraints, which has changed the endothermic reaction into exothermic. Meanwhile, coking in PDH was significantly reduced by the presence of an oxidant in ODH of propane. Therefore, ODH of propane has attracted wide interest and has been studied in recent years. However, the contradiction between the conversion of propane and the selectivity of propene was the intrinsic problem of ODH of propane that required further study. In this work, a novel aluminum/potassium-doped mixed metal oxide catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox was synthesized using a simple co-impregnation method, whose selectivity for propene (83.2 %) and conversion of propane (12.7 %) at 300 °C were the best among all other alkali metal/alkaline-earth metal-doped catalysts. The further discussion illustrated that doping potassium and alumina could synergistically adjust the density of acid sites on the catalyst, establishing an equilibrium between high propane conversion and the ideal propene selectivity. After modification, the density of Brønsted acid decreased, leading to an enhancement in the selectivity of propene. Simultaneously, the addition of steam in the feed gas promotes propene to oxygenates and improves the conversion of propane under the condition of constant contact time. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidative dehydrogenation of propane Mixed metal oxide catalyst Propene Steam Selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propene is an essential organic raw material in the petrochemical industry. It is generally served as the primary raw material for synthesizing polypropene, acrylonitrile, carbonyl alcohol, epichlorohydrin, cumene, acrylic acid, and other products. Currently, it is primarily produced through the catalytic cracking of by-products like naphtha and light diesel oil, as well as through the direct dehydrogenation of propane [1,2]. Propane is used as a feedstock for dehydrogenation to produce propene in order to reduce costs. In recent years, propane dehydrogenation (PDH) has become a well-established commercial process, which is environmentally preferable to obtaining propene from steam cracking and fluid catalytic cracking [3]. However, due to the high energy consumption required for PDH, and issues such as catalyst deactivation via coke formation, its large-scale production is limited to a certain extent [4]. Oppositely, oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane can break through the thermodynamic constraints at lower temperatures due to its exothermic nature [5]. Moreover, the presence of oxidants (such as oxygen) can also alleviate problems such as catalyst deactivation caused by coke formation [6,7]. Consequently, ODH of propane is extensively researched. Metal oxides have high research value as catalysts for the ODH of propane because of their unique chemical coordination and adjustable reducibility. Lattice oxygen is considered the active site of metal oxide catalysts that promote the ODH of propane through the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [8]. Currently, molybdenum-based [9], vanadium-based [9], chromium-based [10], cobalt-based [11,12], and nickel-based [13] metal oxide catalysts have been extensively researched in the realm of mixed oxide catalysts for propane ODH to propene. The hexagonal boron nitride catalyst proposed by Grant et al. was a popular non-metallic boron-based catalyst in recent years with a 14 % conversion of propane, and a 79 % selectivity of propene [14]. Despite this, the challenge of easily deactivating boron-based catalysts still needs to be addressed. Their high activity and selectivity can only be sustained for at most ten to dozens of hours [15], and it is difficult to regenerate them, as the lifetime of these catalysts is much lower than that of mixed metal oxides. Vanadium-based catalysts with remarkable ODH performance have been extensively studied, such as V–Mg–O and VOx/Al2O3 catalytic systems [16–19]. The general view is that an excessive amount of Brønsted acid sites on the surface of vanadium-based catalysts can lead to over-oxidation, which is detrimental to the selectivity of olefins. Some studies have suggested that doping heteroatoms such as alkali metals, is beneficial for improving the selectivity of olefins by reducing the density of Brønsted acid sites [20,21]. For ODH of propane, the limitation lies in the contradiction between propane conversion and propene selectivity. In recent years, many groups have made in-depth research and achieved remarkable results. Since the MoVTeNbOx catalyst developed by Mitsubishi [22] in the 1990s has achieved remarkable success in the selective oxidation of propane to acrylic acid, Mo–V-based mixed metal oxide catalysts have garnered significant attention due to their outstanding performance at low temperatures ranging of 350 to 420 °C. Based on the previous studies, the orthorhombic Mo–V–O catalyst was first synthesized by Katou et al., through a hydrothermal method, which had a propane conversion of 5.9 % and propene selectivity of 30.8 % [23]. In the following studies, extensive research was conducted on Mo–V–O catalysts. For instance, using mesoporous carbon as a template, ternary Mo–V oxide nanocrystals (nano MOVO) were synthesized by a hydrothermal method in a confined space. In ODH of propane, there was a 5.5 % propane conversion and a 57.7 % propene selectivity, respectively [24]. The study by Sadakane et al. [25], pointed out that the crystal structure of Mo–V-based composite oxide catalyst was complex and could not be simply synthesized by a solid-phase method. The structural design of catalysts, selection of metal sources, metal ratios, initial concentration and pH of precursor mixtures, calcination conditions, and other factors need to be considered. Through further research, Ishikawa discovered additional applications of Mo–V–Ox catalysts and achieved significant milestones, including the selective oxidation of ethane [26–28], acrolein [29,30], methacrolein [31], and the ammonia oxidation of light alkanes [32]. The aforementioned groups have conducted extensive research on Mo–V-based catalysts for propane oxidative activation and have achieved remarkable results. However, similar to many other ODH catalysts, the contradiction between the activity of Mo–V-based catalysts and the selectivity of intermediate products remains the primary obstacle to their further development, despite their excellent performance at low temperatures. In this work, Mo–V-based mixed metal oxide catalysts for propane oxidation activation reaction were prepared using the co-impregnation method. Doping potassium and alumina have been found to enhance the synergy among the components of the catalyst by adjusting the density of acid sites. The catalyst can effectively activate and oxidize propane at 300 °C to produce propene with a 12.7 % propane conversion and 83.2 % propene selectivity, which were the highest among all other alkali metal/alkaline-earth metal-doped catalysts. In addition, the selectivity of acetone in oxygenates improved when the feed gas contained a small amount of steam (from 2.4 % to 9.4 %). At the same time, the selectivity of COx decreased (from 13.0 % to 12.7 %), At this time, the molar ratio of feed gas is C3H8/O2/H2O=8/1/12.5. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Materials In this work, ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate, ammonium metavanadate, and salts or hydroxides of metals were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Nano alumina sol was purchased from Guolian Technology Co. Ltd. (Jiangsu, China). All of the chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts The catalysts were synthesized using the co-impregnation method. 6 g ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate and 2 g ammonium metavanadate were dissolved in distilled water at 80 °C and stirred until completely dissolved. Subsequently, alkali metal salt or alkaline earth metal salt was added, followed by a specific amount of aluminum sol (the content of Al2O3 was 20 wt%). Then, 1.6 mol/L dilute nitric acid was added dropwise to the mixture until the pH reached 3. The mixture was continuously stirred at 80 °C until it evaporated to dryness. It was then placed in an oven at 80 °C overnight for drying to obtain a light yellow catalyst precursor powder. The precursor powder was placed into a tubular furnace and roasted in a nitrogen gas flow for 2 h at 600 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. A black solid catalyst powder was then obtained. After pressing and screening, solid catalyst particles with a size of 40–60 mesh were obtained. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic experiments were conducted in a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor with continuous gas flow at atmospheric pressure. The quartz tube had a length of 360 mm, an inner diameter of 12 mm, and an outer diameter of 18 mm. The catalyst bed was located in the middle of the reactor, and the rest was filled with SiO2. Propane, oxygen, and steam are used as feed gases, with the gas flow controlled by the mass flow meters. To ensure safety, the mixed gas in the reactor and at the reactor outlet should be controlled within the explosion limit of propane. In general, the molar ratio of propane to oxygen is 8/1. The composition of the products obtained after reaction evaluation was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC). Nitrogen was used as the carrier gas for the FID channel to analyze the hydrocarbons in the product using a PLOT/Al2O3 chromatography column and FID detector. Hydrogen was employed as the carrier gas for the TCD channel, and the products were pre-separated using a Porpak Q chromatographic column with a TCD detector. The COx in the product were analyzed using a 5A chromatographic column. Likewise, it was confirmed that in a reactor composed only of SiO2 as the bed, propane did not convert at 300 °C. 2.4 Material characterizations To analyze the phase structure of the catalyst, the catalyst samples were packed in a glass holder. The XRD patterns were then recorded using an Empyrean diffractometer produced by PANalytical Company. The diffraction intensities were measured from 5 to 80° with a 2θ step equal to 0.02° for 8 s per point using Cu Kα1, 2 radiation at 40 kV and 30 mA. The specific surface area was calculated from the adsorption data in the relative pressure range of 0.05 to 0.3 using the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method. Total pore volumes were calculated based on the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at a relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.95. The X-ray fluorescence spectrum (XRF) was analyzed using the Axios-Petro spectrometer from PANalytical Company. The PCA-1200 chemical adsorption analyzer, produced by Beijing Bioelectronics Technology Company, was utilized to measure the surface acidity properties of catalysts. A 100 mg sample was subjected to pre-treatment at 300 °C under argon (Ar) gas to eliminate impurities and moisture adsorbed on the catalyst surface. After the pre-treatment was completed, the sample was cooled to 100 °C and subjected to NH3 adsorption under the following conditions: a mixture of 5 vol.% NH3/N2 gas at a flow rate of 40 mL/min was introduced for adsorption for 30 min. Once the adsorption reached saturation, a flow of 40 mL/min of Ar gas was introduced for 20 min to purge the physically adsorbed NH3 from the catalyst surface. Subsequently, the determination of NH3 desorption was conducted under the following conditions: Helium gas was introduced at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The temperature was programmed to increase to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and was maintained at that temperature for 1 min [33]. The spectrum of Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) pyridine absorption-desorption was recorded using a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm-1 [33,34]. Samples to be adsorbed and blank samples of each catalyst were prepared and placed in the oven for overnight drying. The sample to be adsorbed was then exposed to pyridine vapor for 1 hour to facilitate pyridine adsorption. After vacuum pumping, pyridine desorption was carried out in an oven at different temperatures. The surface morphology and microcomposition of the catalyst were analyzed using the Talos F200X field emission scanning transmission electron microscope (TEM) from Thermo Fisher Scientific in the United States. Similarly, the K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) from the company was applied to analyze the valence state changes of oxygen species and active components on the catalyst surface. The analytical instrument utilizes the standard Al Kα X-ray as the excitation source, with an acceleration voltage of 1486.6 eV The measured elements were charge-corrected using C1 s (284.6 eV) as the internal standard. 2.5 Catalytic responses The values of hydrocarbon conversion, selectivity, and yield to products were calculated to quantify the catalysts’ behavior. On a carbon basis, these catalytic responses were obtained after reaching a steady state during the operation of the catalysts. For instance, propane conversion, acrylic acid selectivity, and yield were computed by Eqs. (1), (2), and (3), respectively [22,35]. (1) Conv ersi on of prop ane ( % ) = moles of cons umed prop ane moles of supp lied prop ane × 100 % (2) Sele ctiv ity of prop ene ( % ) = moles of form ed prop ene moles of cons umed prop ane × 100 % (3) Yield of prop ene ( % ) = moles of form ed prop ene moles of supp lied prop ane × 100 % 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalyst was synthesized using the co-impregnation method. In the catalytic testing, various alkali and alkaline-earth metals were used as dopants for comparative analysis, and the results are listed in Table S1. It can be inferred that the doping of potassium species effectively improved the selectivity of the catalyst for the intermediate product propene and reduced the selectivity of COx, which had a better effect than other alkali metals and alkaline-earth metals with propene selectivity of 88.3 %. Obviously, the selectivity of the catalyst is not entirely consistent with the electronegativity of modified metals. For instance, the selectivity of the Cs-doped catalyst for propene is 79.4 %, which is lower than the propene selectivity of the K-doped catalyst. Hibst et al. [36]. have identified the reason for this discrepancy: the concentration of Cs+ ions blocks the active sites for propane oxidation. Consequently, although the selectivity of propene is influenced by the electronegativity of the modified metal [37], the electronegativity of the metal is not the only decisive factor. The influencing factors of propene selectivity still need to be analyzed based on the type of doped metal [20,38]. Several Mo–V-based catalysts were synthesized, which can be expressed as Mo1V0.5Ox, Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox, and Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox, respectively. The test results of several catalysts are listed in Table 1 . For the catalyst Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox, it was found that although the doping of potassium in the Mo1V0.5Ox catalyst could significantly enhance the selectivity of propene (from 72.1 % to 88.3 %), it also led to a significant reduction in the catalyst's activity (from 14.6 % to 7.7 %). Therefore, Al2O3 was doped into the catalytic system using the co-impregnation method to enhance the activity of the catalyst. For ODH of propane, Al2O3 typically enhances the activity of the catalyst. The high acidity of Al2O3 may promote the strong adsorption of propene and other intermediate products on the catalyst, which can easily lead to the production of deep oxidation products [8]. Nevertheless, our experiments indicated that the activity of the catalyst can be improved by doping a small amount of Al2O3 (increasing propane conversion from 7.7 % to 12.7 % and decreasing propene selectivity from 88.1 % to 83.2 %). We speculate that Al2O3 plays a role in balancing the acidic sites in the reaction. However, the amount added should be carefully controlled. The effect of potassium doping amount on the catalytic activity of the Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox catalyst is illustrated in Fig. 1 . Fig. 1a and b display the conversion of propane and selectivity of products in the absence of steam and at a water flow rate of 0.1 mL/min. At the same time, after adding steam to the feed gas, the contact time of the reaction is controlled by adjusting the weight of the catalyst. As the atomic ratio of K to Mo increases, the conversion of propane decreases, the selectivity of propene increases, the selectivity of acetone decreases, and the selectivity of COx decreases. Studies on the selective oxidation of propane indicate that propene is the initial intermediate product [5,39–41]. Subsequently, propene undergoes further oxidation to produce acetone or acrolein, with this process being facilitated by more acidic sites. According to reports [20,21], potassium doping can decrease the number of acid sites. Consequently, the catalyst's activity decreases, hindering the further oxidation of propene to acetone or acrolein. This results in a decrease in the degree of deep oxidation and thus a reduction in COx selectivity, ultimately leading to an enhancement in the selectivity of the intermediate product propene. When the reaction temperature was 300 °C and the flow rate of H2O was 0.1 mL/min, the selectivity of propene in the reaction with steam was lower, and the selectivity of acetone was higher than that in the reaction without steam. The conversion of propane was higher than that without steam, and the selectivity of COx was also lower than that without steam. Apparently, the steam content in the feed gas significantly influenced the product distribution of the reaction. The doping effect of potassium species and alumina was thoroughly researched and identified. Specifically, the effects of doping with potassium and alumina, individually and in combination, and their respective amounts on catalytic performance were investigated (Fig. S1). It was observed that when solely doped with alumina, trace amounts of alumina did not significantly enhance propane conversion (Fig. S1a). In contrast, when exclusively doped with potassium, propane conversion decreased substantially as the amount of potassium increased. However, this trend was effectively mitigated by the presence of alumina, resulting in only a minor decrease in propane conversion, while the selectivity for propene remained relatively high (Fig. S1b). Therefore, we suspected that potassium species may exhibit a synergistic effect with alumina in the ODH process of propane, promoting a balance between propane conversion and propene selectivity. In addition, we investigated the impact of varying amounts of alumina on catalytic performance. Subsequently, we identified the optimal range for alumina addition (Fig. S2). By comparing the effects of feed gas with different steam amounts on the reaction (Fig. 2 ), it is observed that the propane conversion increased slightly with the enhancement in steam amount (Fig. 2a), with the H2O flow rate increasing from 0 to 0.15 mL/min, the propane conversion increased from 12.7 % to 13.5 %. The total selectivity of propene + acetone, surprisingly, did not change significantly in the range of H2O flow rate from 0 to 0.1 mL/min (from 85.6 % to 86.0 %). Further, a decrease in propene and COx selectivity and an enhancement in the selectivity of the oxygenates acetone and acetic acid were observed (Fig. 2b). The changing trend of reaction products with the ratio of alkane to oxygen is illustrated in Fig. 3 . It can be seen in Fig. 3a that as the ratio of alkane to oxygen increased, the conversion of propane gradually decreased (15.7 % when C3H8/O2=2, and 8.9 % when C3H8/O2=10). In contrast, the total selectivity of propene and acetone gradually increased (from 73.6 % to 86.5 %). In Fig. 3b, the selectivity of propene gradually increased (from 68.1 % to 84.5 %), while the selectivity of COx gradually decreased (from 21.7 % to 12.3 %), and acetone and acetic acid's selectivity gradually decreased (5.5 % to 2.0 % and 4.5 % to 0.9 %, respectively). This is because, with the increased ratio of alkane to oxygen, the degree of excessive oxidation in the reaction is restricted. As a result, the reaction products tended to produce more intermediate product propene rather than the more stable acetone. When the ratio of alkane to oxygen is low, propene tends to be further converted into acetone, which is subsequently oxidized to COx. Therefore, controlling the degree of oxidation can enhance the selectivity of intermediate target products. When the reaction temperature was raised to 350 °C, the conversion of propane was 18.2 %, with selectivities of 70.3 % for propene and 10.5 % for acetone. The conversion of propane was 29.8 % at 400 °C. At this time, the selectivity of 56.6 % for propene and 13.6 % for acetone. As the temperature increased, the selectivity of COx significantly rose. It is worth noting that the mentioned temperature is still lower than the conventional temperature typically used in many studies on the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. In addition, for the most effective catalyst, Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox, we tested its performance stability at a reaction temperature of 300 °C (Fig. S3). The results indicated that the catalyst consistently maintained stable activity and propene selectivity during the 48-hour oxidative dehydrogenation reaction of propane. 3.2 Structural characterization of catalysts Various techniques were applied to characterize several catalysts. Three kinds of catalyst samples, Mo1V0.5Ox, Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox, and Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox, were analyzed through the NH3-TPD. The NH3-TPD spectra (Fig. 4 ) showed that the amount of ammonia adsorbed by catalyst Mo1V0.5Ox was significantly larger than that of the other two catalysts. The total amount of acidic sites of several catalysts was in the order of Mo1V0.5Ox> Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox> Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox, we have provided the amounts of acid sites in Table S2. Another notable observation is that the Mo–V–O catalyst contains numerous strong acid sites. However, after doping with potassium species, these strong acid sites nearly disappear. The subsequent introduction of alumina increases the number of strong acid sites once again, resulting in a catalyst with optimal acidity. Subsequently, the pyridine adsorption-desorption method was used to further determine the nature, density, and strength of their surface acid sites [42]. The FT-IR spectra of several catalysts at different pyridine desorption temperatures were recorded using a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer (Fig. 5 ). The presence of two absorption peaks located at 1484 and 1451 cm-1 is related to the Lewis site coordinated with pyridine. In addition, an absorption peak located at 1541 cm-1 was observed in Fig. 5, which is the characteristic peak of the Brønsted acid site [43]. The doping of potassium species resulted in a significant reduction in the acid sites of the Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox catalyst. Subsequently, after adding Al2O3 species, the Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox catalyst showed a significant increase in the amount of acid sites. This phenomenon also confirms our previous speculation that doping potassium species can alter the number of acidic sites on the surface of the Mo–V-based catalysts. In addition, with the increase in pyridine desorption temperature from 50 °C to 150 °C, it is worth noting that the intensities of all the bands decreased. The adsorption amount of pyridine at 150 °C has approached zero, which means that this series of catalyst samples exhibited weak Brønsted and Lewis acidity. Another effect of Al2O3 doping, according to our speculation, is to increase the specific surface area of the catalyst. The elemental composition of the three catalysts obtained by XRF and the specific surface area determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method are listed in Table 2 . The specific surface area of the catalyst modified with potassium decreased slightly (from 4.7 m2/g to 3.7 m2/g). The average pore size change trend calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was consistent with that of the surface area (from 18.2 nm to 10.8 nm). Subsequently, the specific surface area of the Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox catalyst increased slightly after doping Al2O3 (from 3.7 m2/g to 5.2 m2/g). The porous structure of Al2O3 itself will slightly increase the specific surface area of the catalyst. However, it can be seen that the doping of potassium species or Al2O3 has little effect on the specific surface area and average pore size of the catalyst, so it is impossible to accurately determine the effect of doping on the specific surface area and average pore size of the catalyst. Especially for metal oxide catalysts with small specific surface area, weak changes in specific surface area and average pore size will not have a significant impact on the reaction. Therefore, the factor that affects the performance of the catalyst due to changes in specific surface area or average pore size can be excluded. The changes in the average pore size and specific surface area of the Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Fresh) catalyst before use and the Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Used) catalyst after the ODH reaction were also compared. After 48 h of operation, we observed that the average pore size of the catalyst was 13.2 nm, and the specific surface area was 5.4 m²/g. These values showed minimal changes compared to the fresh catalyst, indicating the stability of the mesostructure of the Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox catalyst during the ODH of propane. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was utilized to analyze the surface morphology and micro area composition of the catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Fig. 6 ). It can be observed that the catalyst generally has a cylindrical structure. Furthermore, there was no significant change in the morphology of the catalyst after 48 h of ODH reaction compared to the fresh catalyst. By observing the distribution of elements through energy-dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) mapping, it was discovered that several elements, including doped species, were evenly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst sample. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra of Mo1V0.5Ox, Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox, Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Fresh), and Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Used) catalysts (Fig. 7 ) indicated that the diffraction peaks at 2θ equal to 14.6°, 21.9°, 25.0°, 26.5°, 29.5°, 32.7°, 33.4°, 36.9°, 44.8°, 48.9°, 54.3°, and 58.8° belonged to the characteristic peaks of the crystalline phase V0.95Mo0.97O5 (ICSD, PDF 77–0649), which was the main crystalline phase of the Mo1V0.5Ox catalyst. Additionally, the diffraction peaks located at 2θ equal to 26.0°, 37.0°, and 53.6° indicated the presence of the crystalline phase MoO2 (ICSD, PDF 78–1069). After incorporating potassium and Al2O3 components, the XRD spectra of the Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox and Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox catalysts revealed diffraction peaks located at 2θ equal to 8.2°, 9.2°, 10.0°, 22.9°, 25.6°, 28.9°, and 30.7°, indicated the presence of crystalline phases K2Mo7O20 (ICSD, PDF 82–0069), Mo9O26 (ICSD, PDF 84–1466), Mo17O47 (ICSD, PDF 71–0566), and Mo4O11 (ICSD, PDF 72–0048). This indicates that the valence state of Mo has changed, a finding that was further confirmed and discussed in subsequent experiments. For the Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox (Used) catalyst, the diffraction peaks located at 2θ equal to 12.7°, 23.3°, 25.6°, and 27.3° belonged to the characteristic peaks of the crystalline phase MoO3 (ICSD, PDF 76–1003). The presence of the MoO3 crystal phase indicates that the Mo component in the catalyst underwent further oxidation by the oxygen in the feed gas after the reaction. At the same time, it can also be observed from the curve that the intensity of some diffraction peaks at 26.5°, 36.9°, and 54.3° was weakened. This indicates that as the reaction progresses, the crystal phase undergoes a change during the reaction process. The catalytic performance of catalysts is strongly affected by the valence states of Mo, V, and other elements on the surface. To examine the alterations in the valence states of elements on the catalysts' surface after modification and before and after a reaction, several catalyst samples were tested using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The valence distribution of Mo species was estimated by deconvolution of the Mo 3d spectrum (Fig. 8 a), as described in the literature [44–46]. The binding energies of Mo5+ and Mo6+ in the Mo 3d5/2 region of the catalyst Mo1V0.5Ox were 232.9 eV and 234.0 eV, respectively, with corresponding full width at half maximum (FWHM) values of 1.58 eV and 1.46 eV It can be observed that the Mo 3d spectrum of the K-modified catalyst shifted towards the low valence state, indicating that the Mo6+ species were partially transformed into Mo5+ species. The relative abundance of Mo6+ to the total Mo species decreased from 34.4 at.% to 25.9 at.%. After a 48-hour ODH reaction on the catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox, Mo5+ transitions back towards Mo6+, and the relative abundance of Mo6+ increased from 27.0 at.% to 32.7 at.%. A small amount of Mo4+ species indicated the presence of MoO2, which is consistent with the results from XRD. The deconvolution of the V 2p3/2 region for catalyst samples allowed the identification, based on literature [44]. For the catalyst Mo1V0.5Ox, of two V species at 516.3 and 517.2 eV of binding energy assigned to V4+ and V5+, respectively, with corresponding full width at half maximum (FWHM) values of 1.58 and 1.46 eV (Fig. 8b). After potassium doping, the relative abundance of V5+ decreased from 64.9 % to 59.4 %, as V5+ shifted to V4+. For the catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox, as the reaction progressed, the relative abundance of V5+ decreased slightly from 63.2 % to 61.7 %. The O 1s XPS spectra of several catalyst samples are listed in Fig. 9 . In the case of the Mo1V0.5Ox catalyst, the peak at a binding energy of 530.9 eV corresponds to the characteristic peak of lattice oxygen bound to metal (M–O, including M–O–M), while the peak at 531.8 eV represents the characteristic peak of M–OH oxygen species. After K-modification, M–O (M–O–M) shifted to M–OH, and the relative abundance of M–OH increased from 37.5 at.% to 41.2 at.%. For the catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox, the XPS pattern after a 48-hour reaction indicated that M-O (M-O-M) shifted to M-OH, and the relative abundance of M-OH increased from 38.1 at.% to 40.0 at.%. It indicated that lattice oxygen is consumed, but the change is weak. 4 Discussion 4.1 Brønsted acid sites are unfavorable for propene selectivity In the FT-IR spectra pyridine adsorption-desorption experiments, we compared three catalyst samples: undoped, doped with potassium species, and doped with potassium species and Al2O3. According to the results in Section 3.2 (Fig. 5), the weight and radius of the sample tablet, the characteristic peak area of Brønsted acid or Lewis acid in the spectrum, and other data were collected. The density of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of several catalysts at different pyridine desorption temperatures was roughly calculated using the Beer-Lambert law [47], which uses the extinction coefficient defined by Emeis [48]. Fig. 10 a compares the calculated ratios of Brønsted acid sites for the three catalysts. The effect of different pyridine desorption temperatures on the ratio of Brønsted acid sites is beyond the scope of this paper, as no pattern was observed. The content of Brønsted acid sites is <1/2 for all three catalysts. confirming the slight predominance of Lewis-type acidity, a feature that is particularly evident for the catalyst Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox. The doping of Al2O3 subsequently further increased the density of Brønsted acid sites with a consequent increase in their ratio. According to reports, Brønsted acid is associated with the acetone pathway, which can result in deep oxidation to COx [36,49]. However, the low content of acid sites is not conducive to the activation of propane. This is because the selective oxidation of propane is initiated by the synergistic mechanism of acid-base pairs to abstract H from propane, and the Lewis acid site interacts with the α-H of propane to generate propene [50,51]. As a result, the reaction tends to favor low propane conversion and high propene selectivity [51]. Therefore, the density of acidic sites on the catalyst's surface must be adjusted accordingly to optimize propane conversion and propene selectivity. During the process of propane ODH, propane is initially converted into an oxygen-containing intermediate (which is suggested to be 2-propanol according to the literature [52]), under the influence of Mo–V–Ox. These oxygen-containing intermediates subsequently undergo CO bond cracking due to the catalyst's acidity, resulting in the production of H2O and olefins. The doping of potassium species serves two primary functions: first, it promotes the desorption of propene; second, it works in conjunction with alumina to adjust the catalyst's acidity. However, the introduction of only potassium species into the Mo–V–Ox catalyst results in a significant decrease in catalytic activity [49]. According to Table S2, the amount of strong acid sites nearly disappears after the introduction of potassium species. We believe that strong acid sites play a crucial role in the cracking of oxygen-containing intermediates, and a specific amount of these sites is essential. Building on this, we incorporated alumina, which enhanced the catalyst's acidity [8]. When potassium and alumina are co-doped and modified, the catalyst retains an appropriate amount of strong acid sites, resulting in higher propane conversion and increased propene selectivity. According to Fig. 10a, the ratio of Brønsted to Lewis acid site densities decreases after doping of the Mo1V0.5Ox catalyst with potassium species. This finding aligns with the research conducted by Quintana-Solórzano et al., which indicates that the addition of potassium species leads to a reduction in Brønsted acid sites, with a lesser impact on Lewis acid sites [42]. Consequently, the selectivity for propene increased, while the conversion of propane decreased. The formation of Brønsted acid sites, promoted by alumina, positively contributes to the catalyst's activity [8]. Furthermore, the pyridine-FTIR results indicate that the densities of Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites on the surfaces of catalysts doped with both species are not simply superimposed or canceled out. Thus, we can conclude that doping with potassium and alumina can synergistically modify the density of acid sites on the catalyst, establishing a balance between high propane conversion and optimal propene selectivity. Fig. 10b shows the trends of propane conversion (gradually increasing), propene selectivity (gradually decreasing), and COx selectivity (gradually increasing) for several catalysts with increasing density of Brønsted acid sites, which can validate our above conclusions. In addition, the effect of Lewis acid sites content is illustrated in Fig. S4a. It is important to note that the total acid sites content significantly impacts the performance of the catalyst. Therefore, based on the total acid content calculated through NH3-TPD (Table S2), we have also included a trend curve depicting the relationship between propane conversion rate and propene selectivity as total acid content varies (Fig. S4b). It is evident that as total acidity increases, the conversion rate of propane rises, while the selectivity for propene declines. 4.2 Mo5+ and V4+ positively affects propene selectivity The catalytic test shows that potassium doping can increase the selectivity of propene and reduce the selectivity of oxygenates. According to the XPS results in Section 3.2, we aimed to elucidate the factors contributing to the enhanced catalytic performance from a different perspective, in addition to the variation in acid site density. The catalyst Mo1V0.5K0.03Ox exhibits weaker activity than the catalyst Mo1V0.5Ox, but higher selectivity for propene. The partial transition from Mo6+ species to Mo5+ species explains this phenomenon from one aspect (Fig. 8a). According to the literature, the role of Mo6+ species is to insert oxygen into the intermediate product propene to further generate oxygenates [53], and the decrease in the relative abundance of Mo6+ reduces the catalyst activity [54]. Fig. 11 shows trends in propane conversion, propene selectivity, acetone selectivity, and COx selectivity as the relative abundance of Mo6+ increases, which validates the above statement. After 48 h of propane ODH reaction, the Mo 3d spectrum of the catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox shifted to a higher valence state. Mo5+ species were oxidized to Mo6+ species, indicating that the presence of oxygen in the feed gas during the reaction process can "reactivate" the catalyst, continuously supplement the consumed lattice oxygen, and maintain the activity of the catalyst. It is inferred that this process can provide a long service life for the catalyst. During XPS testing, exposing catalyst samples to X-rays will induce the transition of species valence [44]. Due to the weak transition of Mo4+ species, it is difficult to accurately determine the influence of dopants or the oxidation reaction process on Mo4+ species. Propane is activated by V5+ species, which then breaks the CH bond of propane, resulting in the conversion of V5+ species to V4+ species. The V4+ species are then oxidized by gaseous oxygen to regenerate V5+ species, thereby achieving a balance of V4+ and V5+ [55,56]. As indicated by XPS results in Fig. 8b, when only potassium species were doped, V5+ shifted towards V4+, which can explain the decrease in catalyst activity from one perspective [57], This pattern can be observed in Fig. 11, i.e., an increase in the relative abundance of V5+ leads to an increase in catalyst activity, an increase in the oxidation of propane, an increase in propane conversion, and a decrease in propene selectivity. With the addition of Al2O3, V4+ species transitioned to the higher valence V5+ species. As the ODH reaction progressed, the V5+ species were partially reduced back to V4+ species. This phenomenon may be attributed to the redox of the catalyst during the reaction, this slight change can be ignored, so it can be considered that the catalyst is relatively stable in the propane ODH reaction. As illustrated in Fig. 9, after the K-modification of Mo1V0.5Ox, it is evident that the lattice oxygen transitions from M–O (or M–O–M) to M–OH. As the ODH reaction progresses, M-OH moves towards the lattice oxygen. Toyoshima [58] pointed out through Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations that the M-OH species is a stable and excellent species under thermodynamic conditions. The enhancement of catalytic stability is closely associated with the rapid migration of bulk lattice oxygen, and the movement of oxygen species typically corresponds to the migration of cation species [59]. We concluded that the partial transfer of this oxygen species is one of the reasons why the modified catalyst exhibits weaker activity but higher selectivity, as the relative abundance of M-OH increased, the trends in propane conversion and several product selectivities were opposite to those of Mo6+ and V5+ (Fig. 12 ). In addition, after 48 h of the propane ODH reaction, the oxygen content of the catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox changed only slightly. Ishikawa further studied the type of lattice oxygen and believed that the catalytically active species in Mo–V–Ox were generated by oxygen defects [60]. Therefore, during the reaction process, these oxygen defects support the stability of the catalyst by being continuously consumed and created. This is also consistent with our results. In general, the effects of potassium species and Al2O3 doping on the performance of Mo–V–Ox catalysts are multifaceted. Apart from influencing the number of acid sites, these effects also manifest in the modifications of crystal phase, molybdenum species, vanadium species, and the migration of lattice oxygen. A comprehensive analysis should be conducted from various perspectives. 4.3 Steam promotes propene to form oxygenates Steam is considered to enhance the desorption of intermediate products from the catalyst bed. This helps prevent deep oxidation, leading to an improvement in intermediate products selectivity [39,61]. Under these conditions, it is speculated that water competed with propane, propene, or other intermediates for adsorption sites. The density of acidic sites on the catalyst surface will also change with the increase in surface hydroxyl concentration. At this point, the degree of surface hydroxylation increases [62], which reduces the number of oxygen sites available for alkane adsorption, consequently lowering the reaction rate. It is the reason for the decreased in propane conversion. However, if only steam is added to the feed gas without controlling the contact time, the contact time will be reduced. Therefore the contact time of the reaction was kept consistent for different steam additions by controlling the weight of the catalyst bed. Fig. 2 have indicated that steam has promoted further oxidation of propene to produce acetone and acetic acid (mostly acetone), the conversion of propane increased, yet the selectivity of COx did not increase. Steam has a significant effect on the selective oxidation of propane when using mixed metal oxide catalysts. Some studies have indicated that introducing steam to the feed gas can enhance the selectivity towards oxygenates [63,64]. The impact of steam varies depending on the catalyst used, on some catalysts, steam in the feed gas is necessary for acid formation [65,66]. The influence of water on the catalytic performance in the selective oxidation process is multifaceted. It can alter the reaction pathway and the surface properties of the catalyst simultaneously. To investigate the effect of steam on propane ODH, targeted supplementary experiments were carried out using a Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox catalyst, choosing to carry out the reaction at a temperature of 400 °C to make the trend in the selectivity of the oxygenated products clearer (Fig. 13 ). The pattern of change in propane conversion and in the selectivity of several major products can be seen in Fig. 13. As the water flow rate was elevated from 0 to 0.4 ml/min, the propane conversion increased from 29.8 % to 46.8 %, while the propylene selectivity decreased from 56.6 % to 42.2 %, with the selectivity of COx decreasing and then increasing, and the selectivity of acetone increasing and then decreasing. According to Baca et al. [67], it was pointed out that in the presence of steam in the feed gas, the Lewis acid site was converted to the Brønsted acid site, providing an acidic environment for the conversion of propene to acetone. Similar conclusions have also been mentioned in the research of Ishikawa et al. [29]. Therefore, when controlling for a consistent contact time for each reaction, the presence of water caused a higher density of Brønsted acid sites, promoting the conversion of propene towards the reaction path of acetone, and as the amount of water increased, the density of Brønsted acid sites increased further, and acetone was further oxidized to COx. Thus, it will lead to excessive oxidation and the production of acetic acid or COx, reducing the selectivity of the target product, propene. The conversion of propane is increasing, while the selectivity for propene is decreasing. In the other case, when the water content in the feed gas is low, although propene is oxidized to acetone, the increase in density of the lower Brønsted acid sites is not sufficient to allow further oxidation of acetone, which increases the selectivity of propene + acetone and decreases the selectivity of COx due to desorption of water. As the water content increases, the density of Brønsted acid sites increases, resulting the decrease in acetone selectivity caused by the formation of COx (Fig. 13). This is the reason why the selectivity of COx decreases and then increases while the selectivity of acetone increases and then decreases in Fig. 13. To summarize, we conclude that during the ODH process of propane using this type of catalyst, it is important to decide whether to add steam to the feed gas and adjust the steam according to the requirements. This approach enables us to achieve reaction products with diverse compositions. 5 Conclusions A novel mixed metal oxide catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox doped with aluminum and potassium was synthesized using a simple co-impregnation method. Its propene selectivity reached 83.2 %, and the propane conversion rate was 12.7 % at 300 °C. FT-IR pyridine adsorption-desorption experiments revealed that the concentration of acidic sites on the modified catalyst surface, particularly Brønsted acid sites, decreased. Further discussion suggests that the synergistic doping of potassium and alumina can regulate the density of acid centers on the catalyst, achieving a balance between high propane conversion and optimal propene selectivity. The catalyst was characterized using BET, TEM, XPS, and other methods before and after a 48-hour ODH reaction. The results indicate that the catalyst exhibits good stability throughout the propane ODH reaction. After modification, the Brønsted acid content is reduced, the metal moves toward lower valence states, leading to an enhancement in the selectivity of propene. Additionally, in this study, the reaction temperature is lower than the typical propane ODH reaction temperature. Based on the experimental results, we conclude that the presence of steam promotes the conversion of the intermediate product propene to oxygenates during the reaction. At a temperature of 300 °C and a molar ratio of propane to oxygen of 8:1, the addition of a small amount of steam to the feed gas changes the composition of the oxidation products. The conversion of propane is enhanced and the generation of oxides does not lead to over-oxidation (which increases COx selectivity). coredata.dc:description: Compared with propane dehydrogenation (PDH) technology, oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane is an effective way to break through the thermodynamic constraints, which has changed the endothermic reaction into exothermic. Meanwhile, coking in PDH was significantly reduced by the presence of an oxidant in ODH of propane. Therefore, ODH of propane has attracted wide interest and has been studied in recent years. However, the contradiction between the conversion of propane and the selectivity of propene was the intrinsic problem of ODH of propane that required further study. In this work, a novel aluminum/potassium-doped mixed metal oxide catalyst Mo1V0.5Al0.02K0.03Ox was synthesized using a simple co-impregnation method, whose selectivity for propene (83.2 %) and conversion of propane (12.7 %) at 300 °C were the best among all other alkali metal/alkaline-earth metal-doped catalysts. The further discussion illustrated that doping potassium and alumina could synergistically adjust the density of acid sites on the catalyst, establishing an equilibrium between high propane conversion and the ideal propene selectivity. After modification, the density of Brønsted acid decreased, leading to an enhancement in the selectivity of propene. Simultaneously, the addition of steam in the feed gas promotes propene to oxygenates and improves the conversion of propane under the condition of constant contact time.
